Circuit Analysis:The process of breaking down a circuit of key components and studying each one to see what happens with the others.  Voltage Resistance Current  DC circuts consist of resisters and series in parallel formations.  There goal is to simplify everything to to a resistor which has an equivalent resistance of all resistors combined.  Figuring out the amount of resistance to figure out the amount of current that runs through the battery.  What goes in must come out  The larger the resistance the larger the voltages are

Stranger things!

1:18 i noticed a major defect in the train. If u look at the wheels, you have 2 smaller ones and 2 larger ones. There is a bar that spans the middle big one and the small one. The bar ensures the rpm of the 2 wheels are constant. The problem here is since the wheel diameters are different, these wheels are rotating at different linear ft/min and the train would stall and the wheels would burn out. So in reality this train would never work.....

they used the reciprocal after using a common denominator to add. It would be 5/15 + 3/15 which equals 8/15 and then you use the reciprocal to equal R_eq (not 1/R_eq, that was a mistake on their video editing.) 15/8 =1.875, which they rounded to 1.88 for some odd reason

A real power supply will lower its voltage as you draw more current. But assuming an ideal power supply, parallel resistors will have some voltage drop across all of them. Imagine that each resistor had a different voltage drop. Then charge in the wire connecting the resistors' - sides could convert potential energy into work by falling down the potential difference from one resistor's lead to the other. But then that would equalize the charge, and the cluster would have the same voltage drop once equilibrium was reestablished.

Here is a joke-   Heisenberg, Schrodinger And Ohm are speeding down the highway and get pulled over by a cop. The cop says "Do you know how fast you are going?" Heisenberg responds "No. But I know were we are". The officer thinks this is suspicious and ask to look into there trunk. They let him and he finds a dead cat in it. He ask the three "Do you three know there is a dead cat in here?" Schrodinger responds "We do now". The officer tried to arrest the three but Ohm resist.

I guess my intuition for this must be completely upside-down. Shouldn't the ammeter connected in parallel get less current than if it were connected in series? aPiece OfPi oh no

@jeremywlett  Your intuition about current being diverted in parallel is correct! However think about this: an ammeter barely has resistance. Imagine you are the electrons moving through the circuit. You want to move where there is less resistance. If you connect an ammeter in parallel you are giving electrons a free pathway to move without having to bump into a resistor.

Perhaps it is still confusing because the current flowing through the ammeter will be the same as in series. But the key is, if electricity does not bump into a resistor in a full loop, things will "blow up". Because the battery keeps on giving voltage to the electrons upon every single loop. This is why you need a resistor, not actually to decrease current but to make sure the potential energy of electrons resets every loop.  PS: after learning about the nodal analysis method this makes a lot more sense.

SciPunk215 what step did you take in order to get 1.88 from 0.53?
I divided the number 1 by the number 0.53. (BTW: it looks like they added an annotation correcting the mistake. Kudos to the CrashCourse editors !! Keep up the good work, folks !!)

After solving a lot of equations like this I recognize the pattern and just do it in my head... just take the reciprocal (i.e. divide into 1).  But to be a more precise: We start with 1/Req = 0.53. We notice that the variable in question, "Req", is the denominator. In my mind, I look at the right hand side of that equation and assume 0.53 is the numerator of a fraction with an invisible 1 in the denominator. To solve for Req we cross multiply and we get: Req = 1/0.53

IIGrayfoxII Use Watt's law. P = power dissipated - Watts I = current - Amps V = pressure - Volts The short logic of Watt's law is P=I*V, I=P/V, and V=P/I Use Ohm's law to get the current through, and the voltage drop across, any resistor or group of resistors and you can calculate power dissipation (Watts).
yeah power is Current multiplied by Voltage. Using ohms law rewrites you can express this as any 2 of ohms laws elements. U=IR -> P= I * (IR)= I^2*R I=U/R -> P=(U/R)*U= U^2/R

Different generations have different tastes and ideas of aesthetics. The old black and white films that were all long shots with minimal cuts  or the scenes that took ten or fifteen minutes don'r work after the 1980s. All movies had mostly happy endings, which wasn't the case in classic Greek tragedies or in 1970s films. And having jump cuts like in this video was once thought of as a bad director or an actor who couldn't learn their lines. Now it's a style. The same with the dutch angle, shaky cam, or the fish-eye lens.  And, of course, the topics that interest the audience changes as the culture changes. What made Dr. Strangelove or 2001: a Space Odyssey classics don't work in the fast-paced space action films. And films like Hard Days Night or Head would leave modern film goers wishing the took LSD while Through a Mirror Darkly or Harold and Kumar Go to White Castle will make you feel marijuana is required.
